alternative_title: Employer's tax and reporting for personal bills
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers covering the cost of employees' bills for services or goods
title: Expenses and benefits: personal bills

table.body:
As an employer, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations if you cover the costs of your employees' personal bills for goods or services.

##What's included

What you need to report and pay depends on:

- who arranges for the supply of goods or services
- who pays the supplier
- if your employee pays and you pay them back
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don’t have to report anything to HMRC or pay tax and National Insurance for employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year if:

* you arrange the goods and services
* you pay the supplier directly

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt?

table.body:
If the bills you pay aren’t [exempt](/expenses-and-benefits-personal-bills/whats-exempt "exempt"), you may have to report them to HMRC. You may have to deduct and pay tax and National Insurance on the costs.

##You arrange the goods or services and pay the supplier directly

For employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, or directors:

* report on form P11D, section K 
* pay Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the benefit

##Your employee arranges the goods or services, but you pay the supplier directly

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | - 
Employees [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 per year | Report on form P9D, section A(2) | Add the full cost to earnings and deduct Class 1 National Insurance through payroll
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of more than £8,500 per year | Report on form P11D, section B | Add the full cost to earnings and deduct Class 1 National Insurance through payroll
Directors | Report on form P11D, section B | Add the full cost to earnings and deduct Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

##Your employee arranges and pays the supplier, but you reimburse them

The amount you reimburse counts as earnings, so:

- add it to your employee’s other earnings
- deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]: Pay As You Earn
